units.title: Foundations of Geometry
units.description: Points, lines, planes, segments, angles, and angle relationships.

content.explanation: A point has no dimension (just location). A line extends infinitely in both directions. A plane extends infinitely in two dimensions. Collinear points lie on the same line. Coplanar points lie on the same plane. Two lines intersect at a point. Two planes intersect along a line.

examples.problem: Name 3 collinear points on line AB with C between
examples.explanation: Points on the same line are collinear.
The intersection of two planes is always a line.
Two points determine exactly one line.

content.real_world: Architects use points, lines, and planes to design buildings.

practice_problems.question: Collinear points lie on the same ___
Intersection of two planes is a:
practice_problems.hint: Two planes meet in a line.

practice_problems.question: Three noncollinear points determine a plane.
practice_problems.hint: 3 noncollinear points define exactly one plane.

practice_problems.question: A line extends infinitely in ___ directions
Coplanar points lie on the same:

content.explanation: A segment has two endpoints. A ray has one endpoint and extends infinitely. An angle is formed by two rays sharing an endpoint (vertex). Angle types: acute (<90°), right (90°), obtuse (>90°, <180°), straight (180°). Adjacent angles share a vertex and a side.
content.real_world: Angles appear everywhere: clock hands, door openings, ramps.

practice_problems.question: A straight angle measures ___ degrees
practice_problems.hint: A straight angle is a line.

content.explanation: Complementary angles sum to 90°. Supplementary angles sum to 180°. Vertical angles are opposite when two lines cross — they're always equal. Linear pair: supplementary adjacent angles formed by two intersecting lines.

examples.problem: Vertical angles: one is 40°, the other?

content.real_world: A door opens to create supplementary angles with the wall.

practice_problems.question: Two angles sum to 90°. They are:

content.explanation: Midpoint formula: M = ((x₁+x₂)/2, (y₁+y₂)/2). Distance formula: d = √((x₂-x₁)² + (y₂-y₁)²). These come from averaging coordinates and the Pythagorean theorem, respectively.
content.real_world: GPS uses the distance formula to calculate how far you are from a destination.

units.title: Reasoning and Proof
units.description: Use inductive and deductive reasoning, write two-column proofs.

content.explanation: Inductive reasoning: observe patterns → make a conjecture (guess). Can be disproven by a counterexample. Deductive reasoning: use facts, definitions, and theorems → reach a guaranteed conclusion. Deductive is more reliable.

examples.problem: All dogs are mammals. Rex is a dog. So...

content.real_world: Scientists use inductive reasoning to form hypotheses, then deductive reasoning to test them.

practice_problems.question: Using theorems to reach a conclusion is:
'All squares are rectangles. ABCD is a square. So ABCD is a rectangle.' This is:

content.explanation: A conditional has the form 'If p, then q' (p → q). p is the hypothesis, q is the conclusion. Converse: q → p. Inverse: ~p → ~q. Contrapositive: ~q → ~p. A conditional and its contrapositive are logically equivalent.

examples.problem: Conditional: If it rains, the ground is wet. Converse?
examples.answer: If the ground is wet, it rained.

examples.problem: Contrapositive of 'If sunny, I go outside'
examples.answer: If I don't go outside, it's not sunny

examples.problem: Are a conditional and its converse equivalent?
examples.explanation: The converse may be false even if the original is true.

content.real_world: Legal contracts use conditional logic: 'If payment is late, then a fee applies.'

practice_problems.question: In 'If p, then q': p is the ___
Converse of 'If A then B':
options: If not A then not B
If not B then not A

practice_problems.question: Contrapositive of 'If A then B':
options: If not A then not B
If not B then not A

practice_problems.question: A statement and its contrapositive are equivalent.
Inverse of 'If p then q' is 'If not p then not ___'
Which is equivalent to the original conditional?

content.explanation: A two-column proof lists Statements (left) and Reasons (right). Reasons include: Given, Definition, Postulate, Theorem, Properties (reflexive, symmetric, transitive). Every step must have a justification. Start with Given, end with what you're proving.

examples.problem: Reason for 'If a=b and b=c, then a=c'

content.real_world: Legal arguments follow a proof structure: state a claim, provide evidence for each step.

practice_problems.question: 'If a=b and b=c then a=c' is:
A proof starts with what is ___
Every statement in a proof needs a reason.
Which is NOT a valid reason?

content.explanation: Use algebraic properties as reasons: Addition Property (add same to both sides), Subtraction Property, Multiplication Property, Division Property, Distributive Property, Substitution Property. These justify each step when solving equations.
content.real_world: Programming uses logical proofs to verify that code is correct.

practice_problems.question: Adding 5 to both sides uses the ___ Property
You can multiply both sides of an equation by 0.
practice_problems.hint: You can, but you'd lose information (0=0).

questions.question: Observing patterns to make a guess is:
Contrapositive of 'If A then B':
options: If not B then not A
If not A then not B

questions.question: 'If a=b and b=c then a=c' is:

units.title: Parallel and Perpendicular Lines
units.description: Angle relationships formed by parallel lines and transversals.

content.explanation: When a transversal crosses two parallel lines, it creates 8 angles. Special pairs: Corresponding angles are equal (same position). Alternate interior angles are equal (opposite sides, between lines). Alternate exterior angles are equal (opposite sides, outside lines). Co-interior (same-side interior) angles are supplementary (sum to 180°).

examples.explanation: Opposite sides, between the parallel lines.

content.real_world: Railroad tracks are parallel lines. A road crossing them is a transversal.

practice_problems.question: If one corresponding angle is 70°, the other is ___
If one co-interior angle is 110°, the other is ___
If alternate interior angle is 55°, the other is ___

content.explanation: You can prove lines are parallel if: corresponding angles are equal, alternate interior angles are equal, alternate exterior angles are equal, or co-interior angles are supplementary. These are the CONVERSES of the parallel line theorems.

examples.problem: If corresponding angles = 65° each, are lines parallel?

content.real_world: Builders use angle measurements to ensure walls are parallel.

practice_problems.question: Equal alternate interior angles prove lines parallel.
To prove parallel, corresponding angles must be:
Alt. interior angles 45° and 45°. Lines are ___
If alt. interior angles differ, lines are NOT parallel.
practice_problems.hint: They must be equal for parallel.

lessons.title: Slopes of Parallel and Perpendicular Lines

content.explanation: Parallel lines have equal slopes (m₁ = m₂). Perpendicular lines have negative reciprocal slopes (m₁ · m₂ = -1). Horizontal lines (slope 0) are perpendicular to vertical lines (undefined slope).
content.real_world: City streets often form parallel and perpendicular grids.

lessons.title: Writing Equations of Parallel and Perpendicular Lines

content.explanation: To write a parallel/perpendicular line through a point: 1) Find the required slope (same or negative reciprocal). 2) Use point-slope form: y-y₁=m(x-x₁). 3) Convert to slope-intercept if needed.
content.real_world: Engineers calculate perpendicular supports for bridges.

practice_problems.question: Parallel to y=-3x+5 through (1,2):
practice_problems.hint: Wait... y-2=-3(x-1)=y=-3x+5. Actually let me check: y-2=-3x+3, y=-3x+5. Yes!

questions.question: If corresponding angles are 65° and 65°, lines are ___
Alternate interior angles with parallel lines are:

units.title: Triangle Congruence
units.description: Prove triangles congruent using SSS, SAS, ASA, AAS, and CPCTC.

content.explanation: By sides: equilateral (3 equal), isosceles (2 equal), scalene (0 equal). By angles: acute (all <90°), right (one =90°), obtuse (one >90°), equiangular (all 60°). Triangle Angle Sum: angles add to 180°. Exterior angle = sum of two non-adjacent interior angles.

examples.explanation: All angles equal, all sides equal.

examples.problem: Third angle if two are 50° and 70°

content.real_world: Triangles are the strongest shape in construction — used in bridges and trusses.

practice_problems.question: Sum of angles in a triangle = ___°
Third angle if two are 45° and 90°: ___°

content.explanation: SSS (Side-Side-Side): If all 3 sides of one triangle equal all 3 sides of another, the triangles are congruent. SAS (Side-Angle-Side): If 2 sides and the INCLUDED angle are equal, the triangles are congruent. The angle must be BETWEEN the two sides.

examples.problem: △ABC: AB=5, BC=7, CA=8. △DEF: DE=5, EF=7, FD=8.
Two sides and a NON-included angle match. Congruent?
examples.explanation: SSA is NOT a congruence shortcut.

content.real_world: Manufacturing uses congruence — every copy of a part must match the original exactly.

practice_problems.question: In SAS, the angle must be:
SSA is a valid congruence shortcut.
If triangles are congruent, all parts match.

content.explanation: ASA (Angle-Side-Angle): If 2 angles and the INCLUDED side are equal, triangles are congruent. AAS (Angle-Angle-Side): If 2 angles and a NON-included side are equal, triangles are congruent. Note: AAA does NOT prove congruence (only similarity).

examples.explanation: Two angles and the side between them.
Two angles and a non-included side.
Same shape but could be different size.

content.real_world: Surveyors use angle measurements to determine if land plots are congruent.

practice_problems.question: ASA requires:
practice_problems.hint: Angles and the side between them.

practice_problems.question: AAS requires:
practice_problems.hint: Angles and a side not between them.

content.explanation: CPCTC: Corresponding Parts of Congruent Triangles are Congruent. After proving triangles congruent (by SSS, SAS, ASA, or AAS), you can conclude any corresponding parts are equal. This is used as the FINAL step after establishing congruence.

examples.problem: After proving △PQR ≅ △XYZ, what is ∠P equal to?

examples.answer: Prove triangles congruent FIRST, then use CPCTC for parts
examples.explanation: Must establish congruence before using CPCTC.

content.real_world: Quality control: if two manufactured parts are congruent, every measurement must match.

practice_problems.question: CPCTC stands for: Corresponding ___ of Congruent Triangles are Congruent
The order of letters in congruence statements tells you:
CPCTC can be used as the reason for a step in a proof.
practice_problems.hint: It's a valid reason after establishing congruence.

questions.question: Third angle if two are 35° and 80°: ___°

units.title: Similarity
units.description: Understand similar figures, AA/SAS/SSS similarity, and proportional reasoning.

content.explanation: A ratio compares two quantities: a:b or a/b. A proportion states two ratios are equal: a/b = c/d. Cross-multiply to solve: ad = bc. Scale factor is the ratio between corresponding lengths of similar figures.
content.real_world: Map scales use proportions: 1 inch = 50 miles.

content.explanation: Similar triangles have same shape, different size. All angles equal, sides proportional. AA (Angle-Angle): 2 pairs of equal angles → similar. SAS Similarity: 2 pairs of proportional sides with included angle equal. SSS Similarity: all 3 pairs of sides proportional.
content.real_world: Photographers use similar triangles to calculate distances with shadows.

practice_problems.question: All rectangles are similar.
practice_problems.hint: A 1×2 rectangle isn't similar to a 1×5.

practice_problems.question: If scale factor is 3, and a side is 5, corresponding side = ___

content.explanation: Triangle Proportionality Theorem: A line parallel to one side of a triangle divides the other two sides proportionally. Midsegment: connects midpoints of two sides, is parallel to the third side, and half its length.

examples.problem: In △ABC, DE∥BC with AD=3, DB=6, AE=4. Find EC.
AD=2, DB=5, AE=4. Is DE∥BC if EC=10?

content.real_world: Engineering uses proportional triangles for structural calculations.

practice_problems.question: AD=4, DB=8, AE=3. If DE∥BC, EC=___
A midsegment is parallel to the base.
practice_problems.hint: Always parallel to the third side.

content.explanation: Similar triangles can find unknown heights and distances. Set up proportions with corresponding sides. Shadow problems: object height / shadow length = other object height / other shadow length (sun's rays are parallel).

examples.problem: Photo enlarged 3x. If original is 4×6, new size?

content.real_world: Architects use scale models — similar figures — to design buildings before construction.

practice_problems.question: Shadow: 5ft person, 3ft shadow. 12ft shadow tree height=___
Model car 1:24 scale. Real car 12ft. Model=___ inches
6ft person, 4ft shadow. Flagpole 30ft shadow = ___ ft tall

units.title: Right Triangles and Trigonometry
units.description: Pythagorean theorem, special triangles, and intro to SOH-CAH-TOA.

content.explanation: In a right triangle: a² + b² = c² where c is the hypotenuse (longest side, opposite the right angle). Pythagorean triples: (3,4,5), (5,12,13), (8,15,17), (7,24,25) and their multiples. Converse: if a²+b²=c², the triangle is right.
content.real_world: Builders use 3-4-5 triangles to check if corners are exactly 90°.

practice_problems.question: The hypotenuse is:
practice_problems.hint: Always the longest, opposite the right angle.

content.explanation: 45-45-90: legs equal, hypotenuse = leg×√2. If leg=a, sides are a, a, a√2. 30-60-90: shortest side opposite 30°, hypotenuse = 2×short, long leg = short×√3. Sides are a, a√3, 2a.
content.real_world: 45-45-90 triangles appear in the diagonal of a square. 30-60-90 in equilateral triangles cut in half.

content.explanation: For a right triangle with angle θ: sin(θ) = Opposite/Hypotenuse (SOH). cos(θ) = Adjacent/Hypotenuse (CAH). tan(θ) = Opposite/Adjacent (TOA). The 'opposite' and 'adjacent' sides depend on WHICH angle you're looking at.
content.real_world: Pilots use trigonometry to calculate glide paths and approach angles.

content.explanation: Use trig to find missing sides or angles. To find a side: set up the trig ratio and solve. To find an angle: use inverse trig (sin⁻¹, cos⁻¹, tan⁻¹). Example: if sin(θ)=0.5, then θ=sin⁻¹(0.5)=30°.
content.real_world: Surveyors measure angles of elevation to calculate building heights.

units.title: Circles
units.description: Parts of circles, central and inscribed angles, arc length, and sector area.

content.explanation: Circle parts: center, radius (center to edge), diameter (2×radius, through center), chord (segment with both endpoints on circle), secant (line through two points), tangent (line touching at exactly one point, perpendicular to radius at that point). Circumference = 2πr = πd. Area = πr².
content.real_world: Wheels, clocks, and pizzas are all circles with practical applications.

practice_problems.question: A tangent is perpendicular to the radius at the point of tangency.
A chord that passes through the center is a:

content.explanation: Central angle: vertex at center, measure = intercepted arc. Inscribed angle: vertex on circle, measure = HALF the intercepted arc. So inscribed angle = central angle / 2 for the same arc. An inscribed angle in a semicircle = 90°.
content.real_world: Satellite dishes use the angle properties of circles to focus signals.

practice_problems.question: Central angle is ___ the inscribed angle for same arc:
Central=140°. Inscribed angle for same arc=___°

content.explanation: Arc length = (θ/360°) × 2πr = (θ/360°) × circumference. Sector area = (θ/360°) × πr² = (θ/360°) × total area. θ is the central angle in degrees. Think of it as a fraction of the whole circle.
content.real_world: Pizza slices are sectors. A quarter of a pizza is a 90° sector.

practice_problems.question: A full circle has central angle:

content.explanation: Tangent-radius: tangent ⊥ radius at point of tangency. Two tangent segments from the same external point are equal. Chord properties: perpendicular from center to chord bisects the chord. Equal chords are equidistant from center.

examples.problem: Tangent from point P to circle, radius=5, distance to center=13. Tangent length?
Two tangents from P: PA=8, PB=?
examples.explanation: Tangent segments from same point are equal.

content.real_world: Gears in machinery rely on tangent line properties for smooth rotation.

practice_problems.question: Radius=3, distance to center=5. Tangent length=___
Two tangents from P: one is 7. Other=___
A tangent is perpendicular to the radius.
Chord=24, perpendicular from center bisects it. Half=___

units.title: Area, Surface Area, and Volume
units.description: Calculate area, surface area, and volume for various 2D and 3D figures.

content.explanation: Rectangle: A=lw. Triangle: A=½bh. Parallelogram: A=bh. Trapezoid: A=½(b₁+b₂)h. Regular polygon: A=½(apothem)(perimeter). Composite figures: break into simpler shapes and add/subtract areas.
content.real_world: Landscapers calculate area to determine how much sod or fertilizer to buy.

lessons.title: Surface Area of Prisms and Cylinders

content.explanation: Prism SA = 2(base area) + (perimeter of base)(height). Cylinder SA = 2πr² + 2πrh. The lateral area is the 'wrapper' around the sides. Think of unfolding the 3D shape into a flat net.
content.real_world: Gift wrapping requires calculating surface area to cut enough paper.

practice_problems.question: SA of a cube with side s:

content.explanation: Volume = Base area × height. Prism: V = Bh where B is the area of the base. Cylinder: V = πr²h. Cube: V = s³. These all follow the same principle: base area times height.

examples.problem: Triangular prism: triangle base 6, height 4, prism height 10

content.real_world: Aquarium designers calculate volume to know how much water is needed.

lessons.title: Volume of Pyramids, Cones, and Spheres

content.explanation: Pyramid: V = ⅓Bh. Cone: V = ⅓πr²h. Sphere: V = (4/3)πr³. SA of sphere = 4πr². Pyramids and cones are ⅓ of their prism/cylinder counterparts.
content.real_world: The Egyptian pyramids, ice cream cones, and basketballs are all these shapes.

practice_problems.question: Cone volume compared to cylinder (same r,h):
